data.title: Danish Milk. Grey or blue?

data.text:
Do you drink milk? We drink lots of it in our house. And â€“ whatâ€™s more â€“ weâ€™re living dangerously without a safety net and still choosing to drink (and enjoy) cowâ€™s milk! [Gasps from the audienceâ€¦]

Now, Iâ€™ve mentioned before the hazards of not being able to decipher Danish food packaging : remember these little pots of pasteuriserede Ã¦ggehvider â€“ pasteurized egg whites? The mother of a French friend of mine mistook them for Danone mini yoghurts. And put one in the grandchildâ€™s packed lunchbox. Ha! ğŸ˜‰

Been there, done that! Well, not exactly the egg-whitey thing. But do I remember leaving Scotland at the tender age of 21 to go and work in the small (but perfectly formed Duchy of) Luxembourg and being totally baffled by the dairy section at my local supermarchÃ©. I knew to look for â€œlaitâ€ but had no idea if I was buying semi-skimmed, full-fat or long-life. Repeat the scenario holidaying in Spain, Greece, Italy, etc, etc, etc.

Things are a lot easier here in Denmark because those crazy but lovable Danes have a clever milk coding system. The colour on milk cartons is standardized. Thus, if you know what kind of milk you like, you can easily find it. But you need to know the Danish name for it selvfÃ¸lgelig! So in order to make your trip to the supermarked a little less hazardous, hereâ€™s my run down on the various types of milk youâ€™re likely to encounter in Denmark:

full-fat â€“ sÃ¸dmÃ¦lk â€“ dark blue carton

semi-skimmed â€“ letmÃ¦lk â€“ pale blue carton

0.5% fat â€œminiâ€ milk â€“ minimÃ¦lk â€“ light grey/blue carton

skimmed â€“ skummetmÃ¦lk â€“ grey carton

.

But â€“ hov â€“ what about all those other dairy products lurking in the cooler section, just waiting to confuse you?

whipping cream â€“ piskeflÃ¸de â€“ red carton

non-whipping cream for coffee â€“ kaffeflÃ¸de â€“ orange carton

buttermilk â€“ kÃ¦rnemÃ¦lk â€“ green carton Unless â€“ selvfÃ¸lgelig â€“ it has a picture of an apple on it. Then itâ€™s Ã¦blemost â€“ applejuiceâ€¦ ğŸ˜‰

.

And the countless other types of yoghurts/soured milk products will just have to wait until another blogpost!

My kids love skummetmÃ¦lk and my favourite is sÃ¸dmÃ¦lk. Whatâ€™s your favourite tipple?

Happy drinking. Oh, and â€œmoooooooooooâ€!
